title: The Historical Reliability of Acts
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

What is the book of Acts? Is it a reliable history of the early church and the life of the apostle Paul? Or is it a rather late, largely fictional retelling of these events? It is safe to say that modern New Testament scholarship strongly favors this latter option. But what if there is compelling evidence telling in favor of the historical reliability of Acts? And if so, what are the ramifications of this evidence for the Christian faith and Christian apologetics? This video will explore these questions arguing that there is excellent evidence for the reliability of the book of Acts and that this fact serves an critical role in making the case for the resurrection of Jesus.

title: The Rationality of Belief in Miracles: Answering Hume and his Contemporary Defenders
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

Is it rational to believe that miracles happen based upon testimony? David Hume famously argued that it is not. But despite over 200 years of steady criticism, there remain a number of philosophers who defend Hume's argument. This video reviews much of the literature surrounding this debate and argues that neither Hume's original argument nor modern reconstructions thereof are successful.

title: A Case For Free Will
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

In this video, I’m going to bring together some of my thoughts on the topic of free will. I’ve been pondering this issue on and off for the past several years and my perspectives are, in many regards, unique. I hold to an indeterministic conception of free will which would probably be considered libertarian by many although I have developed some reservations about using that term. The plan for this video is as follows: First, I will offer a brief overview of the contemporary options in the free will debate and get some working definitions on the table. I will then present what I take to be the most plausible account of free will, namely an agent-causal account. I will present an original, although not decisive, argument for why we should think that this account is true. Finally I shall address the two most common objections to agent-causal indeterminism. I will explore and reject the idea that this account of free will is incoherent and reduces to random chance. Then I shall critique the notion that scientific developments in neuroscience has shown that our decisions are predetermined.

title: Why I Don't Use The Freethinking Argument | A Critique of Tim Stratton
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

Do we need libertarian free will in order to think rationally? Is determinism somehow epistemically self-defeating? And if so, then does this provide us with some reason to think that God exists? An apologist by the name of Tim Stratton strong believes so. This video will critically assess his defenses of these claims and argue that they are ultimately unsuccessful. After that, I will develop and defend an argument which will show that one cannot simultaneously affirm both the third and fourth premises of Stratton's argument at the same time.

title: Is The Bible Our Highest Authority?
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

Many Christians believe that it is wrong to offer unbelievers evidence for the truth of Christianity. In particular, such objections can be found among Christian presuppositional apologists. They argue that the traditional method of apologetics dishonors Scripture by not giving it the respect it is due. The concern is that offering evidence for the truth of Scripture gives evidence a greater weight of authority than Scripture. In this video, I hope to show that the traditional apologist can answer this type of argument in a two-fold fashion. Once we firmly grasp what it means to say that Scripture is one’s highest authority, it will become clear that this belief is not in conflict with presenting evidence for the truth of Scripture. In short, traditional, evidence-based, apologetics is harmonious with the affirmation that Scripture is the Christian’s highest authority.

title: The Argument From Forced-Fulfilled Prophecy
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

There are numerous arguments for the historical reliability of the Gospels based upon their contents. These include the accuracy of the Gospel authors with respect to geographical locations and names, as well as local customs, and cultural references. Then there are undesigned coincidences, unnecessary details, unexplained allusions, and unified personalities throughout the Gospels. All of these arguments have in common the idea that certain details within the Gospels are unlikely to have been fabricated because they are difficult to engineer, and correspond to the known characteristics of reliable testimony. Together, they form a powerful abductive argument for the historical reliability of the Gospels. Most of these arguments have already received attention both in writing and in videos. However, there is a further argument which I would add to this repertoire of arguments which has not hitherto been developed in any detail, at least not to my knowledge. I call this the argument from forced-fulfilled prophecy.

title: Why I Don't Use The Argument From Logic (The Lord of Non-Contradiction)
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

Many theists have thought that a divine conceptualist account of logic provides the theist with a ready account of the ontology of logic and, as a result, they think that the existence of logic can be used as an argument for theism. The most sophisticated attempt at providing such an argument comes from James N. Anderson and Greg Welty in their 2011 paper “The Lord of Non-Contradiction: An Argument for God from Logic”. I am actually on-board with most of the premises of this argument. However, I think that the chief flaw emerges in a subtle and unjustified inference from necessary truth to necessary existence. This video will explain the argument and the rationale behind each premise, before developing this point as a fundamental objection to the argument from logic.

title: How to Defeat the Argument From Undesigned Coincidences: A Skeptic's Guide
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

The argument from undesigned coincidences is an argument which is used in tandem with a series of other arguments to present a holistic argument which concludes that the four canonical Gospels represent a generally historically accurate picture of the life and deeds of Jesus. Lydia McGrew served to revive the argument within contemporary apologetics with the publication of her 2017 book Hidden in Plain View. The argument has, of course, sparked a reaction from many skeptics. I would have liked to make a video defending the argument from undesigned coincidences from the criticisms which it has faced. However, after seeing how badly almost all criticisms of the argument misunderstand it, I thought I would try doing something a bit different. In this video, rather than defend the argument from the extremely misguided criticisms which it has faced heretofore, I will instead sketch a strategy for what a successful refutation of this argument would actually look like. The title of this video is somewhat misleading. I am personally persuaded that the argument from undesigned coincidences is a good argument for the historical reliability of the Gospels. As such, I do not think that the response to the argument which I will sketch here can actually be successfully completed. But I am offering it to skeptics in the hopes that, by seeing what it would take to successfully invalidate the argument from undesigned coincidences, they will better understand the argument from undesigned coincidences.

Chapters:

00:00 - Introduction
02:28 - The Logic Behind the Argument
05:20 - Defining and Identifying Undesigned Coincidences
08:25 - Examples of Undesigned Coincidences
13:55 - The Larger Whole Behind the Texts
19:31 - Inference to the Best Explanation
22:15 - The "Divide and Conquer" Strategy
32:45 - A Shortcoming in the Strategy
33:15 - Conclusion

title: Making Sense of Old Testament Violence
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

The Old Testament in the Bible contains many very challenging passages for modern Christians. Some of the rules and regulations just seem arbitrary such as the well-known dietary laws prohibiting foods like pork and shellfish, or laws prohibiting the mixing of different types of fabric. Some of these seem very cruel such as commands to stone disobedient children to death and to cut off the hand of a woman who touches a man’s genitals. Some of these passages are actually disturbing such as verses which describe the proper treatment of slaves, and implicitly endorse the acceptability of capturing enemies and turning them into slaves. More troubling still are verses which seemingly approve of capturing enemy women and forcing them to marry Israelite soldiers. And of course, most troubling of all are the commands from God to wipe out the Canaanites including non-combatants like women, children, and even infants. This video will explore these issues and how Christians have responded to the challenges posed by these texts. I will caution against various extremes before proposing what I see as being the most promising way to understand them.

01:40 - A Brief Autobiography
04:05 - Some "Solutions" Which Don't Work

title: Why I Don't Use The Moral Argument For Theism
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

In this video, I present 5 general challenges for moral arguments for theism. I consider various attempts to evade these challenges. Although some challenges can be circumvented, I argue that others cannot.

00:22:46 - Ethical Intuitionism
00:30:53 - Partners in Guilt
00:44:57 - Deliberative Indispensability
00:59:01 - Challenge 2: Do Moral Facts Need Grounding?
01:00:38 - Challenge 3: How Does God Explain Morality Anyway?
01:02:16 - Challenge 4: Wielenberg's Robust Moral Realism

title: Who Wrote the Gospels?: The Case for Matthew, Mark, Luke and John
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

Virtually everything that we can know about Jesus comes from the four Gospels contained in the New Testament. The Gospels are, by far, our earliest and best historical sources regarding the life, ministry, and teachings of Jesus. Since the Gospels are so central to our understanding of Jesus, it is important that we know where this information is coming from. It is important that we know who authored the Gospels, that the authors were well placed to know they were talking about, and that what they report is true. But who exactly wrote the Gospels? Were they in a good position to know what they were talking about? And are their accounts trustworthy?

title: The Synoptic Problem Part 5: A Response to @ApocalypseHere on Markan Priority

In this video, I respond to some criticisms leveled against my critique of Markan priority by  @ApocalypseHere. title: The Synoptic Problem Part 4: The Internal Evidence for Matthean Priority
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

In my last video, I asked my viewers to temporarily lay aside the internal evidence bearing on the Synoptic problem for the sake of letting the early Church have their say. We saw that, while some disagreement may have existed over the exact order of Mark and Luke, there was complete agreement on the priority of Matthew. But that is just one leg for the Two-Gospel Hypothesis to stand on. There is another category of internal evidence which is equally compelling and which we will explore in this video. 
This evidence largely comes from apparent examples of Mark combining or conflating Matthew and Luke’s narratives together. This so-called argument from conflation, if successful, decisively shows that Mark was written after Matthew and Luke for both of these Gospels would clearly have to exist in order for Mark to conflate them. We shall examine this argument in detail before considering some more internal facts about Mark which suggest that it was written third.

Sources:

Evidence of Conflation in Mark? A Study in the Synoptic Problem - Thomas R. W. Longstaff

The Synoptic Problem: A Critical Analysis -  William R. Farmer

title: The Synoptic Problem Part 3: The External Evidence for Matthean Priority
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

In my last two videos, I explained the nature and scope of the Synoptic problem and critiqued the arguments which undergird the foundation of most modern Synoptic hypotheses: the theory of Markan priority. In this video, I begin the task of building a positive case for an alternative hypothesis. In my next video, we will explore the internal evidence which strongly suggests that Matthew and Luke wrote their Gospels first, and that Mark was written last. But for now, I want to leave those sorts of considerations aside and examine a different category of evidence. In this video, I want to see what sort of Synoptic theory we arrive at if we only consider what our earliest witnesses have to say about the composition of the Gospels.

title: The Synoptic Problem Part 2: A Critique of Markan Priority
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

In this video, I critically assess the major arguments which have been cited to support the theory of Markan priority both in the past and in the present. I conclude that all of them fail for a variety of reasons. The aim is to show that the case for Markan priority has been vastly overstated and oversold. This, of course, is no proof that the Gospel of Matthew was written first or that the Gospel of Mark was written third. We shall explore the external and internal evidence for these conclusions in two future videos. The only conclusion that I reach here is that there is no justification to be had for the theory of Markan priority despite the confidence with which it is widely held. However, it is my hope that this video serves to clear away some of the bias against the the Patristics, and motivates us to take what they have to say about the Synoptic Gospels seriously.

title: The Synoptic Problem Part 1: Introduction
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

In this video, I give a broad overview of the Synoptic problem and its relevance to Christian apologetics. I explain what the problem is supposed to be and I offer a survey of some of the most commonly proposed solutions to it. This video sets the stage for a thorough critique of the arguments for Markan priority and a two-part positive case for Matthean priority.

title: The Classical Evidentialist Approach To Religious Epistemology: Interview With Dr. John M. DePoe
description:
In this video, Dr. John DePoe joins me to discuss a classical foundationalist, internalist, and evidentialist approach to religious epistemology. He lays out the basic of this view, contrasts it with alternatives, and then answers some common objections to it.

Apologies for some of the technical problems. Unfortunately there was a storm while this interview was conducted which interfered with the internet connection making the video out of sync with the audio. It should still be fully understandable.

title: What's Wrong With Presuppositional Apologetics | A Response to Greg Bahnsen
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

In this video I offer an overview of Van Tilian Presuppositionalism and offer a response to (arguably) the most popular proponent of it - Greg Bahnsen. Specifically I address the main arguments he sets forth in chapter three of his book Presuppositional Apologetics Stated and Defended. Bahnsen primarily utilizes the logocentric predicament and the problem of induction to bolster his case. I offer solutions to both problems along with a critique of epistemic circularity and a case for acquaintance foundationalism. I realize that this video will not be the final word on this subject. But I do hope it serves to foster fruitful dialogue and takes a step towards furthering the conversation between Presuppositionalists and Evidentialists.

title: In Defense of Classical Foundationalism
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

In my last two videos I introduced the regress argument for epistemic foundationalism and argued that the foundations of knowledge must be internal. Although classical foundationalism has impressive historical precedent, it is currently unpopular. In contemporary epistemology, the prevailing opinion is that classical foundationalism is simply outdated and untenable. In this video, I wish to challenge this assumption and argue that rumors of foundationalism’s death are premature. Foundationalism is more than capable of meeting the objections leveled against it.

title: Can You Know Anything? Epistemology and the Regress Problem
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

So many bad beliefs are traceable to bad epistemology. Epistemology is incredibly important and it is for this reason that I decided to make a video series introducing viewers to the study of knowledge and defending my own version of classical foundationalism. In this video, I introduce the regress problem and look at the four main solutions to the problem. I argue that foundationalism alone offers a satisfactory answer.

title: A Critique of Eternal Security | Part 3 | The Book of Hebrews
description:
In my previous video, I built a case for believing that a genuine believer can forfeit his faith, become an unbeliever, and lose his salvation. I made this case using passages outside of the book of Hebrews. But in this video, we are going to focus on the warnings within the book of Hebrews. It is the Arminian position that these warnings are addressed to genuine believers and that the warnings are against losing one’s salvation. This video will evaluate and critique each of these alternate interpretations. I am dedicating an entire video to just these passages because of the sheer number of proposed alternatives. This is a through examination of the warnings in Hebrews.

title: A Critique of Eternal Security | Part 2 | The Case Against Eternal Security
description:
In this video we will begin examining the Biblical evidence which teaches that a genuine believer really can forfeit their salvation. Once again, there is so much evidence against eternal security that we will have to explore it in two parts. Some of the strongest warnings come from the book of Hebrews. As we shall see, Calvinists and other believers in eternal security carry out the most tortured of exegesis to escape the conclusion that these warnings really teach that believers can be lost. But in this video, we shall restrict ourselves to warnings outside of Hebrews. This is the Biblical case against eternal security.

title: A Critique of Eternal Security | Part 1 | The Case For Eternal Security Considered
description:
I'm dividing my case against eternal security into three parts because there is just way too much material to pack it all into one video. I realize this is a sensitive topic for many Christians and I truly do not want to cause anyone to doubt their salvation. But I am firmly convinced that eternal security is a false doctrine and that it needs to confronted.

title: A Critique of Limited (Definite) Atonement
description:
If Jesus died for all, does that mean all will be saved? Can sins be punished twice? Did Jesus waste His blood? Does a general atonement divide the Trinity? Does Scripture teach that the atonement was limited to just the elect? I take on these questions and more in this video.

title: A Critique of Unconditional Election | Rom 8:29-30, Eph 1, 2 Thess 2:13, Jn 8:47, 10:26, Acts 13:48
description:
Unconditional election is the lynchpin of the TULIP. If this point is false, so are the points that follow.  Calvinist have a number of other passages that they can marshal in support of this doctrine. In this video, we will explore these passages and show that none of them require unconditional election to be true.

title: Answering Jesus Mythicism: Part 1 | Josephus
description:
Click here to support my research: https://patreon.com/FaithBecauseofReason?utm_medium=unknown&utm_source=join_link&utm_campaign=creatorshare_creator&utm_content=copyLink

Click here to make a one-time donation: https://paypal.me/davidpallmann?country.x=US&locale.x=en_US

Among atheists there is a popular movement to deny that Jesus ever existed as a historical person. Those who deny Jesus’ historical existence have received the labeled mythicists. This view is not taken seriously by scholars and therefore it receives little attention. However, due to its growing popularity, I will tackle some of their arguments in this series. Although I intend to treat mythicist arguments with respect, it needs to be stressed that scholarship does not consider this view reasonable. With the possible exception of Richard Carrier, there are no credentialed experts who would defend this view. With that in mind, let’s proceed to examine the historical evidence for the existence of Jesus. This is answering Jesus Mythicism part 1.

title: The Ontological Argument
description:
Among the classical arguments for God’s existence, one of the most famous (and most controversial) is the ontological argument. This argument seeks to demonstrate that God necessarily exists, and that this logically follows from the very concept of what God is. It is a frequently misunderstood argument, and many objections simply misunderstand it. It has been defended by some of the greatest philosophical theists both in the past and in the present. So just what is this controversial and provocative argument? This video presents the ontological argument for God’s existence.

title: A Critique of Theistic Evolution
description:
I’ve been asked many times why I hold to intelligent design instead of theistic evolution. Throughout this series I have tried to explain my scientific reasons for being skeptical of evolution. The lack of scientific for evolution and the mounting evidence against it is, and always has been, my primary reason for rejecting it. However, I have other reasons for rejecting theistic evolution as well. It is the purpose of this video to explain why I think this view is problematic. This is a critique of theistic evolution.

title: The Origin of Life and the Case for Intelligent Design
description:
Theories of evolution attempt to study how life diverged from a common ancestor and spread over the earth. However, contrary to much of popular thought, evolution doesn’t demonstrate, but rather assumes the origin of life. Natural selection can only act once a living organism already exists. But then, how did life begin? Is there a naturalistic explanation? This video will assess various naturalistic theories of life’s origin, and argue that they all fail. Life, and more specifically the DNA that is required for life is best explained by an intelligent being rather than materialistic natural processes. It is time to explore the origin of life.

title: Mutation and Natural Selection: Is it Enough?
description:
In my previous two videos, I argued that the usual arguments for common descent based on similarities between organisms and the fossil record are unsuccessful. These video were intended to show that there is really no evolution to explain. However, even if there was, is there a viable mechanism that could accomplish this grand evolutionary story? According to Neo-Darwinism, natural selection acting on random mutations is all that is needed to explain the complexity and diversity of living organisms. But, is this really enough? How much change can really be accomplished? New evidence is showing us that Neo-Darwinism is very limited in what it can actually do. So limited, in fact, that it cannot be the full explanation for the development of life on earth.

title: Debate: Is Intelligent Design True? Jared McComb vs David Pallmann
description:

title: Examining the Fossil Record
description:
In my previous video, I examined several common arguments for common ancestry and refuted them. Most of these arguments were based on genetic, molecular, or anatomical similarities. However, such evidences can only be used to either confirm or contradict a theory of common descent based on the fossil record. The fossil evidence will always have to do the heavy lifting for any case either for or against evolution. While the fossil record as a whole is problematic for evolutionists, they have some candidate fossils that they claim demonstrate common descent. So, in this video we will examine the fossil record.

title: A Critique of Universal Common Ancestry
description:
In my previous video, I introduced the theory of intelligent design and answered some preliminary objections to it. Intelligent Design’s competition, the theory of evolution, has two major pillars. The first is that all life descends from a single common ancestor, and second is that purely natural forces are sufficient to accomplish this change. This video is aimed at the first of those two claims. If universal common descent is historically false, then it doesn’t matter if natural forces can accomplish it or not. So here I am challenging a central dogma of modern biology. This is a critique of common ancestry.

title: Introduction to Intelligent Design
description:
In the world around us we see amazing creatures. Organisms that display complexity on level that baffles the mind. As the scientific evidence builds, the more amazed we’ve become at the intricate details within biological systems. Can this complexity be reasonably explained by purely naturalistic causes? Or is there a need for a designing intelligence in the origin and development of life on earth? This series will take an in-depth look at the data and argue that standard evolutionary explanations are insufficient and that intelligence and foresight are indeed required. Welcome to intelligent design.

title: Answering Who Created God?
description:
In my previous video, I examined ten common objections to the Kalam Cosmological argument for God’s existence. I showed that none of them successfully refute it. However, some of you may have noticed that I didn’t address a very widespread and influential objection, namely “Who Created God?” Although I, along with every professional philosopher (including atheists) consider this to be a terrible objection to God’s existence, I’m dedicating a whole video to it because it comes up quite often. This is Answering “Who Created God?”

title: Is Biblical Inerrancy Important? (Interview with Steven Carr)
description:
Biblical inerrancy has long been a pillar doctrine for the Christian faith.  It's often simply assumed by believers. However, in recent decades, this long held belief has been challenged as being empirically false, outdated, unhelpful, and even harmful. The so-called "Battle for the Bible" is alive and well. In this episode, Dave interviews Reasonable Faith chapter director, Steven Carr, on why he believes inerrancy is both true and defensible.

title: What is Conditionalism? (Interview with J. P.  Wooten and Chris Date)

title: Faith Because of Reason Live Stream
The Kalam Cosmological Argument
description:
Among the many arguments for God’s existence, one of the most popular is the Kalam Cosmological Argument most famously argued by Christian philosopher William Lane Craig. The argument is simple, and takes the following form:

1.Whatever begins to exist, has a cause
2.The universe began to exist
3.Therefore, the universe has a cause
